sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Cerebrovascular accident, In hypertensive patients with left ventricular hypertrophy; Prophylaxis: initial, 50 mg ORALLY once daily
  • Cerebrovascular accident, In hypertensive patients with left ventricular hypertrophy; Prophylaxis: maintenance, 100 mg ORALLY once daily; additionally, hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 to 25 mg ORALLY once daily may be given with losartan 50 or 100 mg daily
  • Diabetic nephropathy, In Type 2 Diabetes and History of Hypertension: initial, 50 mg ORALLY once daily; maintenance, 100 mg ORALLY once daily (based on BP response)
  • Erythrocytosis: 25 to 50 mg ORALLY daily
  • Heart failure: initial, 12.5 mg ORALLY once daily; titrate at 7-day intervals to 25 mg, then 50 mg daily (based on response)
  • Hypertension: initial, 50 mg ORALLY once daily
  • Hypertension: maintenance, 25 to 100 mg ORALLY once daily or in 2 divided doses

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• Alport syndrome-like hereditary nephritis: 0.44 to 2.23 mg/kg/day ORALLY; MAX dose, 50 mg/day ORALLY if weight under 50 kg or 100 mg/day ORALLY if weight 50 kg or more, was administered in a clinical trial
  • Hypertension: (6 yr and older): 0.7 mg/kg ORALLY as tablet or suspension once daily, MAX 50 mg daily

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• liver disease: starting dose 25 mg ORALLY once daily
  • volume-depleted patients: starting dose 25 mg ORALLY once daily

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Cerebrovascular accident, In hypertensive patients with left ventricular hypertrophy; Prophylaxis
  • Diabetic nephropathy, In Type 2 Diabetes and History of Hypertension
  • Hypertension
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Alport syndrome-like hereditary nephritis
  • Cardiovascular event risk, Reduction
  • Diabetes mellitus; Prophylaxis
  • Diabetes mellitus - Hypertension
  • Diabetic nephropathy, In Type 1 Diabetes
  • Diabetic nephropathy, In Type 2 Diabetes
  • Erectile dysfunction
  • Erythrocytosis
  • Gout
  • Heart failure
  • Hypertension - Renal impairment
  • Hyperuricemia
  • IgA nephropathy
  • Impaired cognition
  • Kidney disease, Nondiabetic
  • Left ventricular hypertrophy
  • Raised intraocular pressure
  • Recurrent atrial fibrillation; Prophylaxis
  • Systolic hypertension, Isolated

mono.title: Black Box Warning
mono.mono:
Oral (Tablet)
Drugs that act directly on the renin-angiotensin system can cause injury or death to the developing fetus. Stop therapy as soon as possible when pregnancy is detected.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to losartan or any product components
  • concomitant use with aliskiren in patients with diabetes

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Black Box Warning:
  • -- drugs that act directly on the renin-angiotensin system can cause injury or death to the developing fetus; discontinue as soon as possible when pregnancy is detected.
  • -- fetal and neonatal injury such as oligohydramnios, renal failure, anuria, skull hypoplasia, hypotension, and death have been reported with second and third trimester exposure; discontinue as soon as possible when pregnancy detected; monitoring recommended
  • Cardiovascular:
  • -- symptomatic hypotension may occur in volume-depleted patients, including those on diuretic therapy; dose reduction may be required
  • Endocrine and Metabolic:
  • -- hyperkalemia has been reported; increased risk of electrolyte imbalances in patients with renal impairment with or without diabetes
  • Hepatic:
  • -- use caution in patients with hepatic impairment; dose reduction may be required
  • Renal:
  • -- caution in patients with bilateral or unilateral renal artery stenosis due to increases in serum creatinine and BUN having been reported
  • Other:
  • -- angioedema, including swelling of the larynx and glottis, causing airway obstruction or swelling of the face, lips, pharynx, or tongue has been reported rarely; some of these patients previously experienced angioedema with other drugs, such as ACE inhibitors
  • -- use caution in patients with severe congestive heart failure as oliguria, progressive azotemia, acute renal failure, and death have been reported with ACE inhibitors
  • Concomitant use:
  • -- avoid aliskiren in patients with renal impairment (GFR less than 60 mL/min)
  • -- use with other drugs causing blockade of the renin-angiotensin system such as ACE inhibitors and aliskiren increases risk of hypotension, syncope, and renal dysfunction, including acute renal failure; monitoring recommended

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Losartan: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

mono.title: Adverse Effects
mono.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Chest pain (12%), Hypotension (7%)
  • Endocrine metabolic:Hyperkalemia (7%), Hypoglycemia (14%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (15%)
  • Hematologic:Anemia (14%)
  • Neurologic:Asthenia, Dizziness (3%)
  • Respiratory:Cough (10%)
  • Other:Fatigue
Serious
  • Hepatic:Hepatotoxicity
  • Musculoskeletal:Rhabdomyolysis
  • Renal:Acute renal failure
  • Other:Angioedema

mono.title: Mechanism Of Action
mono.mono: Losartan potassium is a reversible, non-competitive, angiotensin II receptor antagonist. It deters vasoconstriction and aldosterone-secreting effects by specifically intercepting the binding of angiotensin II to the AT(1) receptor.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Oral: time to peak concentration, 1 h
  • Bioavailability: 33%
  • Bioavailability: (hepatic insufficiency) about 2-times higher
  • Effect of food: slows absorption and decreases Cmax
  • Carboxylic acid (active metabolite), Oral: time to peak concentration, 3 h to 4 h

sub.title: Distribution
sub.mono:
• Vd: 34 L
  • Protein binding: 1.3%
  • Carboxylic acid (active metabolite), Vd: 12 L
  • Carboxylic acid (active metabolite), Protein binding: 0.2%

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Hepatic; P450 CYP2C9 and CYP3A4,
  • Active metabolite: Carboxylic acid metabolite

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Fecal: (intravenous) 50%
  • Fecal: (oral) about 60%
  • Renal: (intravenous) 45%
  • Renal: (oral) 35%, 4% unchanged, 6% as active metabolite
  • Dialyzable: no (hemodialysis)

sub.title: Elimination Half Life
sub.mono:
• about 2 h
  • Carboxylic acid (active metabolite): about 6 h to 9 h

mono.title: Administration
mono.mono:
Oral
may be taken with or without food

mono.title: Monitoring
mono.mono:
• blood pressure, heart rate
  • renal function, electrolyte panel (eg; potassium, sodium)

mono.title: How Supplied
mono.mono:
• Generic
    Oral Tablet: 25 MG, 50 MG, 100 MG
  • Cozaar
    Oral Tablet: 25 MG, 50 MG, 100 MG

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
ANGIOTENSIN II ANTAGONISTS
USES: Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARB) are used for the treatment of hypertension. EPIDEMIOLOGY: Exposures are common, but toxicity is rare and deaths have not been reported following single-substance exposures. PHARMACOLOGY: Angiotensin II is an endogenous peptide that binds to angiotensin receptors, causing vasoconstriction and stimulation of aldosterone release. Angiotensin receptor blockers are competitive antagonists at these receptors. TOXICOLOGY: Excessive antagonism of angiotensin receptors causes vasodilation and hypotension. MILD TO MODERATE TOXICITY: Mild hypotension and tachycardia, hypokalemia, asymptomatic hypoglycemia, muscle cramps and dizziness have been reported. SEVERE TOXICITY: Severe toxicity has not been observed with these agents. ADVERSE EFFECTS: Common adverse effects include hypotension and dizziness. Angioedema has been reported rarely.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
ANGIOTENSIN II ANTAGONISTS
  • Support: MANAGEMENT OF MILD TO MODERATE TOXICITY: Administer IV fluids for hypotension. MANAGEMENT OF SEVERE TOXICITY: Severe toxicity has not been reported following exposure to these agents. Provide the usual supportive treatment for any symptoms and consider co-ingestion of other medical conditions.
  • Decontamination: PREHOSPITAL: Not recommended. HOSPITAL: Decontamination is unlikely to be necessary as most ingestions remain asymptomatic. Consider activated charcoal after very large recent ingestion or if more toxic co-ingestants are a concern.
  • Airway management: Airway management is unlikely to be required following overdose. Perform early orotracheal intubation in patients with signs of airway obstruction from angioedema.
  • Antidote: There is no antidote for poisoning from these agents.
  • Enhanced elimination procedure: These agents are highly protein bound; hemodialysis is unlikely to be of any benefit.
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor vital signs and mental status. Monitor serum electrolytes and glucose in symptomatic patients.
  • Patient disposition: HOME CRITERIA: Healthy children and adults can be managed at home if overdose was inadvertent and no signs or symptoms are present. OBSERVATION CRITERIA: Any patients with deliberate overdose or more than mild symptoms should be sent to a health care facility for evaluation. Patients with significant cardiovascular disease, those on other cardiodepressant agents (eg beta blocker) and those who have ingested more than 4 pills or 320 mg valsartan should be referred to a healthcare facility. ADMISSION CRITERIA: Any patient with persistent hypotension should be admitted to the hospital. CONSULT CRITERIA: Consult a poison center or medical toxicologist for assistance in decision making whether or not admission is advisable, managing patients with severe toxicity, or in whom the diagnosis is not clear.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
ANGIOTENSIN II ANTAGONISTS
TOXICITY: Severe toxicity has not been described following isolated overdose from these medications. An adult developed mild toxicity after ingesting 2240 mg valsartan. Azilsartan oral doses up to 320 mg once daily for 7 days were well tolerated in healthy adults during clinical trials. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: Varies with agent. AZILSARTAN: ADULT: 80 mg orally once daily. CANDESARTAN: ADULT: Total daily dose can range from 8 to 32 mg. EPROSARTAN: ADULT: 400 to 800 mg daily in single or divided doses. IRBESARTAN: ADULT: 150 to 300 mg once daily. LOSARTAN: ADULT: 25 to 100 mg orally daily. TELMISARTAN: ADULT: 20 to 80 mg orally daily. VALSARTAN: ADULT: 80 to 320 mg daily. PEDIATRIC: No dosing information available for these agents.

mono.title: Clinical Teaching
mono.mono:
• Patient should avoid activities requiring coordination until drug effects are realized, as drug may cause dizziness.
  • This drug may cause diarrhea, asthenia, or fatigue.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of hypotension.
  • Advise patient against sudden discontinuation of drug.
  • Patient should consult healthcare professional before using potassium supplements or potassium-containing salt substitutes.
